prompt: Assess social identity theory and its applications to intergroup relations, prejudice, and organizational behavior.

criteria.name: Core Concepts
criteria.description: Explains social categorization, identification, and comparison; in-group bias; self-esteem hypothesis.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Accurate, nuanced explanation including depersonalization and contextual factors.
Discusses minimal group paradigm, intergroup bias, and boundary conditions; contrasts with self-categorization theory.
performance_descriptors.good: Covers major studies with acceptable accuracy.

criteria.name: Applications
criteria.description: Applies theory to prejudice reduction, conflict, and organizations.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Proposes evidence-informed strategies (e.g., superordinate identities, contact conditions) and organizational identity interventions.
Evaluates scope conditions, role of norms, and interplay with realistic conflict theory and system-justification perspectives.
performance_descriptors.good: Notes several critiques with some analysis.

key_points: Define core processes and minimal group paradigm findings.
Explain when and why in-group bias emerges or attenuates.
Apply to prejudice reduction via contact and superordinate goals.
Discuss organizational identity, mergers, and culture.
Contrast with alternative theories and note limitations.
llm_questions: Summarize the minimal group paradigm and its implications.
What conditions optimize intergroup contact to reduce prejudice?
How can superordinate identities reduce conflict?
Apply social identity theory to organizational change.
Compare social identity with realistic conflict theory.
